summary: Simon talks about technical/automation mechanics
mainText: 'Not yet, much later after launch because we are dealing a lot of missing core features. Its on the horizon though!'

summary: Simon clarifies the QA testing
mainText: 'Internal QA tomorrow, no external, before anyone asks :P'

summary: Simon gives report on the morning's Hytale test
mainText:
'Tested Hytale exploration mode gameloop this morning for 2 hours, no crashes, lots of fun moments. Still lots of work ahead to make it good, focusing on small wins for fast development. Large scale QA starts tomorrow. 

Morning notes: NPCs are still acting weird sometimes but can be fixed over time. Knockback on enemies feels wrong, needs complete overhaul. We added back shovel tool but made it AoE dig, now itâ€™s actually useful and fun. Mining still feels bad, needs to implement momentum feature and potentially have the signature ability system to tools as a whole (like weapons) so we can have fun coming up with abilities (probably post launch).

Side note: Non-creative (exploration mode) building improvements are happening. Block placement is starting to feel good, rotations and connected blocks works well. Today I need to test our builders bench with new changes. The problem is that we have way too many blocks for building and honestly its a mess, dozen of edge cases for crafting and I want to simplify and make it fun, not tedious so players feels like empowered when building and not restricted, but need to keep immersion in mind. Its critical to get it right because its a game where building is core to the game experience and at the moment its not there just yet. Months ago it was very very frustrating to build, now its actually decent but still need improvements. Today we have small changes that might just make it work well. 

Extra note: Massive progress over the past week, being on our own PC has accelerated progress by so much. However it has personally slowed me down because I have been dealing with interviews, clips, screenshots, QnA and other things. It was important to do, communication is critical so everyone understands the state of the game. The team has been very busy anyway so it was probably a good thing I didnâ€™t put more on their plates.

Will do more reports as we progress if you guys like it.'

summary: Simon requests community ideas for Technoblade tribute in Hytale

I want the community involved in this, please share your ideas for what would feel like a meaningful tribute! 

He was a big part of our journey with Hypixel and I wish for him to be part of this one as well.'

summary: Slikey says the singularity means most of the mining operation is over.
mainText: 'Yep, there may still be some nuggets there but the big mining operation is over. We have culled the branches and if there is anything, we cherry pick it. We have already moved far past what was already on there. The minimap for example didn't exist on any of the branches - it's new.'

summary: Slikey discusses singularity; state of codebase
mainText: 'After the singularity and the modernization of the codebase, we are probably in the best state of the source it has ever been during development - still far from the standard we hold ourselves to, but the devs are performing some miracle right now. I have never seen anything like this before.'

summary: Simon on shaders ruining the curated Hytale experience

summary: Simon continues, re: shaders
mainText: 'Note that we have lots of plans to improve the game rendering/shaders over time and it will evolve over the years ahead!'

summary: Simon answers Q about shaders in Hytale
mainText:
'Not in the short term, we are making too many changes to the rendering and we donâ€™t want to create an ecosystem where everyone has different shaders and makes our artists lives complicated when we evolve the game forward in the future.
We will explore options later on, but at the moment no! Sorry! We evaluated the pros and cons.'

summary: Slikey gives information about the branches; "singularity event."

(NOTE: Previous version of this tweet was deleted and reposted with corrected wording.)

summary: Slikey discusses Linux support
mainText: 'No idea, we haven't tried it. We are trying to get native support for PC platforms including Linux as some of our team members like Linux. We'll run tests if we can't get Linux ready for launch'

summary: Slikey answers server architecture question
mainText:
'Sorry for missing your question. The protocol is the determining factor here. Usually game updates don't alter the protocol but in case that happens, we plan to have a compatibility layer in the future so that you have some time to update your mods and server. I expect us to mess it up early into early access but for that we allow users to select the "previous" game version so that they can still join your server and update their game when you updated the server.
We understand this problem a lot as we had to maintain version compatibility for a dozen versions over at Hypixel and we want to make it as painless as possible.'

We will have client and server side anticheat in the future as well.

Game runs quite well when connecting to a server, I suspect our min specs will be much lower for players joining their friends or servers.'

summary: Mewen says the team will consider different types of controllers, like the Adaptive Controller from Microsoft`
mainText: '100%! Even before reaching consoles, we're planning for controller support. We already try to minimize the number of keybinds as much as possible, but it's proven quite difficult. We'll also consider different types of controllers, like the Adaptive Controller from Microsoft'

summary: Mewen says they will assess text resizing options
mainText: 'Ah gotcha! Yeah, we'll assess what options make sense for the game, and we'll get there step by step!'

summary: Simon says damage numbers are an in-game option

summary: Mewen on communication
mainText:
'That'd help with not being surprised by NPCs/players not in your field of view. A ping wheel to help with communication is something I'm thinking about too.

The gist is that we're open to any suggestions that would help those folks and we'll see how we can apply them to Hytale!'

summary: Mewen responds about Hard of Hearing accessibility features.
mainText:
'Heya! A major principle we try to apply as much as possible is that nothing is conveyed by sounds only (or only by color, etc...), so that helps a bit.

Although it only goes so far, having a visual audio cue wheel (like in Fortnite) is something I'd like to try out. 1/2'

summary: Mewen talks about multi-press feature/controller schema.
mainText:
'Hey! Nothing is set in stone, so any feature can make it as long as it fits the game.

Since Hytale is pretty keybind-heavy, a feature like multi-press could prove pretty useful indeed, same goes for being able to change the controller schema based on the context'

summary: Simon responds to request about PVP
mainText:
'I'll see what I can do next week about recording some bits, but the current goal isn't PvP balance or minigames.
However, I think it's important to show bits of it so that it attracts server owners and modders, or players who want to run private PvP worlds! 

The combat was designed with PvP in mind, which is why many of the weapons lunge forward and the movements are fast-paced.'

summary: Mewen discusses accessibility
mainText: 'Alongside making the movement controller feel as good as possible, accessibility will be my other main focus. I'll strive to make Hytale accessible to as many players as possible! We already have some priorities, and we'll collaborate with the community to deliver what they need!'

summary: Simon addresses belief that his statements on Hytale being not good enough is just reverse psychology.
mainText:
'When I say Hytale is not good enough, I genuinely mean it. It's not some reverse psychology trick! 

Real talk: We are using a 4-year-old game build with over 300 versions (branches) of prototypes that we Frankenstein together in record time into a single branch. None of it was meant to be released this quickly and in this way. 
There are barely any game progression mechanics configured, and we have to implement them all in record time to make it somewhat enjoyable. 
Of course, I'm confident it's going to be "ok" for release. However, this is the current situation we are dealing with, on top of all the bug fixes, refactors, clean-ups and other ongoing issues that we are facing. We inherited a true hardcore engineering and design challenge, and we are on the clock to deliver early access. 

The exploration of the game is fun, don't get me wrong, but man, I wish we had more time to get a few more features or configurations in to enhance that experience, but no, we break the curse of release and fix later. This will come at a significant cost; some people will be permanently convinced the game is doomed to remain in this state, unaware that this is an authentic early access experience. I hope that people who share the game will explain the situation we are in and how we got here.  Keep in mind, the gameplay video doesn't show much of the gameloop because, well, there isn't much of it. Combat, game vibe, and exploration are great fun, but there needs to be mechanics to keep it going over time.

One thing I have learned over time is to enjoy the painful feedback. It is the most critical part of making games and improving yourself as a game designer. Of course, you have to be filtering out the ones that want to steer you in their own vision of what the game should be, so it's a balancing act. 

When I read negative feedback on the gameplay video, I don't get defensive or hurt. I'm literally like, "Yep, they are not wrong" or "Why do they think like this? How can I solve their problem?" This has taken me years to get to that point. Our community, over the last 14 years on MC, has not been shy about giving us their feedback.

The one thing I can promise is that the game is owned by someone who cares and understands the situation, and I will do my best to empower my team to make a great game, however long it takes. This time, with all of you along for the ride, if you wish to be a part of it.'

summary: Simon says it was a one in a million chance everything lined up.
mainText: 'If only you knew all the pieces that had to fall in place for this to happen, it's truly a miracle. 1 in a million chance all of this lined up, some of which can't ever be told unfortunately'
